intro: Eriophyllum lanatum var. hallii, commonly known as the Hall’s velvetleaf, is a perennial herb native to the western United States. It is characterized by its dense, woolly foliage and clusters of small, yellow flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. The plant typically grows in dry, open habitats such as grasslands and rocky slopes. Its leaves are covered in fine, soft hairs, giving it a distinctive, velvety appearance. It plays an important role in supporting local pollinators and is often found in disturbed or arid environments.
